clusters.title: Remains of 4 more Israeli hostages handed over by Hamas
clusters.neutral_headline: Hamas Releases Bodies of Hostages, Ceasefire Faces Test
bullet_summary: Hamas said it was facing obstacles as not all the burial sites had been identified
Palestinian militant group’s move comes after Israeli authorities said they would impose limits on aid into Gaza
Israel’s military said it opened fire on people who it says approached Israeli forces operating in the northern Gaza Strip
On October 13, 2025 Hamas handed over four bodies - whom the Israeli military said they have now identified - leaving 24 still to be returned under the terms of the ceasefire agreement

items.title: Remains of 4 more Israeli hostages handed over by Hamas
items.standfirst: The return of Israeli hostages is a cornerstone of the Gaza peace plan, which called for Hamas to hand over all remaining hostages – 20 living and 28 dead – by Monday.
items.content: The return of Israeli hostages is a cornerstone of the Gaza peace plan, which called for Hamas to hand over all remaining hostages – 20 living and 28 dead – by Monday.

items.title: Hamas releases bodies of four more deceased hostages
items.standfirst: Hamas released the remains of four more deceased hostages to the Red Cross on Tuesday, in addition to the four bodies returned on Monday. There are still 20 bodies left that need to be brought back to Israel. CBS News senior White House and political correspondent Ed O'Keefe has more.
items.content: Hamas released the remains of four more deceased hostages to the Red Cross on Tuesday, in addition to the four bodies returned on Monday. There are still 20 bodies left that need to be brought back to Israel. CBS News senior White House and political correspondent Ed O'Keefe has more.

items.title: Trump says Hamas will disarm or "we will disarm them"
items.standfirst: President Trump proclaimed peace in the Middle East on Monday, but warned of violence on Tuesday as his Gaza peace deal lurches toward phase two. CBS News senior White House and political correspondent Ed O'Keefe reports. Then, Jon Alterman, with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, joins with analysis.
items.content: President Trump proclaimed peace in the Middle East on Monday, but warned of violence on Tuesday as his Gaza peace deal lurches toward phase two. CBS News senior White House and political correspondent Ed O'Keefe reports. Then, Jon Alterman, with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, joins with analysis.

items.title: Israel limits aid into Gaza in dispute over hostage remains as ceasefire faces test
items.standfirst: Hamas accused of breaching agreement by withholding bodies of hostages but Palestinian militants say they face obstacles in retrieving themThe fragile ceasefire in Gaza faced its first test on Tuesday when Israel said the flow of aid into the devastated Palestinian territory would be cut by half and the crucial Rafah border crossing with Egypt would not open as planned, blaming Hamas for delays in the return of bodies of hostages.The militant group handed over the remains of four hostages to the International Committee of the Red Cross on Tuesday night, bringing to eight the number of bodies transferred since the US-brokered ceasefire took hold, leaving 20 to be accounted for. Hamas said it was facing obstacles as not all the burial sites had been identified. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas accused of breaching agreement by withholding bodies of hostages but Palestinian militants say they face obstacles in retrieving themThe fragile ceasefire in Gaza faced its first test on Tuesday when Israel said the flow of aid into the devastated Palestinian territory would be cut by half and the crucial Rafah border crossing with Egypt would not open as planned, blaming Hamas for delays in the return of bodies of hostages.The militant group handed over the remains of four hostages to the International Committee of the Red Cross on Tuesday night, bringing to eight the number of bodies transferred since the US-brokered ceasefire took hold, leaving 20 to be accounted for. Hamas said it was facing obstacles as not all the burial sites had been identified. Continue reading...

items.title: Hamas returns remains of four more hostages, as Israel returns 45 deceased Palestinians, Red Cross says
items.standfirst: Hamas returned the remains of four more hostages to Israeli authorities and Israel returned the remains of 45 Palestinians to Gaza on Tuesday, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross, as President Donald Trump warned the militant group that it must disarm.
items.content: Hamas returned the remains of four more hostages to Israeli authorities and Israel returned the remains of 45 Palestinians to Gaza on Tuesday, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross, as President Donald Trump warned the militant group that it must disarm.

items.title: Families of dead hostages urge US to ‘leave no stone unturned’ to have them returned
items.standfirst: Returning the bodies of 28 hostages was part of the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas but only four have been handed overThe families of missing dead Israeli hostages have written to the US special envoy Steve Witkoff to urge him to “pull out every stop and leave no stone unturned” in forcing Hamas to bring their relatives home from Gaza.The return of 28 dead hostages was part of the agreement that ushered in a ceasefire, but only four have so far been handed over. Continue reading...
items.content: Returning the bodies of 28 hostages was part of the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas but only four have been handed overThe families of missing dead Israeli hostages have written to the US special envoy Steve Witkoff to urge him to “pull out every stop and leave no stone unturned” in forcing Hamas to bring their relatives home from Gaza.The return of 28 dead hostages was part of the agreement that ushered in a ceasefire, but only four have so far been handed over. items.title: Demands mount for Gaza aid to flow and Hamas to hand over more remains

items.content: So far the Gaza ceasefire is holding, but calls are getting louder for Hamas to hand over more hostages' remains, and for Israel to allow in more aid.

items.title: Hamas searches for missing bodies of Israeli hostages
items.standfirst: The International Committee of the Red Cross said it will take time to hand over the remains of the Israeli hostages killed in the Israel-Hamas war, given the difficulties of finding bodies amid Gaza's rubble. On October 13, 2025 Hamas handed over four bodies - whom the Israeli military said they have now identified - leaving 24 still to be returned under the terms of the ceasefire agreement.
items.content: The International Committee of the Red Cross said it will take time to hand over the remains of the Israeli hostages killed in the Israel-Hamas war, given the difficulties of finding bodies amid Gaza's rubble. On October 13, 2025 Hamas handed over four bodies - whom the Israeli military said they have now identified - leaving 24 still to be returned under the terms of the ceasefire agreement.

items.content: As Israeli hostages are freed and Palestinian prisoners and detainees released — and after President Donald Trump's lengthy address to Israel’s parliament on Monday — focus is shifting to what comes next.

items.title: Who are the 20 hostages released by Hamas?
items.standfirst: More than two years after they were abducted during the terrorist attack that launched the Israel-Hamas war, all remaining living hostages have been returned to Israel from the Gaza Strip.
items.content: More than two years after they were abducted during the terrorist attack that launched the Israel-Hamas war, all remaining living hostages have been returned to Israel from the Gaza Strip.

clusters.title: Madagascar crowds cheer as military unit seizes power
clusters.neutral_headline: Madagascar Military Seizes Power, President's Whereabouts Unknown
bullet_summary: Crows celebrated in the streets of the capital Antananarivo after an elite army unit said it had seized power from the president
The situation in Madagascar escalated on Tuesday as the army announced it was taking control of the country, dissolving most governing institutions except for the lower house of Parliament
President Andry Rajoelina’s whereabouts remain unclear; he is reportedly in hiding and may have left the country
An elite Madagascar military unit said it has taken power in the country after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina on October 14, 2025

items.title: Madagascar crowds cheer as military unit seizes power
items.standfirst: Crows celebrated in the streets of the capital Antananarivo after an elite army unit said it had seized power from the president.
items.content: Crows celebrated in the streets of the capital Antananarivo after an elite army unit said it had seized power from the president.

items.title: Madagascar army says it has taken control following Rajoelina’s impeachment
items.standfirst: The situation in Madagascar escalated on Tuesday as the army announced it was taking control of the country, dissolving most governing institutions except for the lower house of Parliament. Colonel Michael Randrianirina, who led a mutiny of an elite army unit over the weekend, said the military would run the country alongside a transitional government for up to two years while elections are arranged. President Andry Rajoelina’s whereabouts remain unclear; he is reportedly in hiding and may have left the country. He has refused to resign despite growing calls for his exit following weeks of protests, which began as a youth-led outcry over water and power utilities before evolving into a broader rejection of his leadership.
items.content: The situation in Madagascar escalated on Tuesday as the army announced it was taking control of the country, dissolving most governing institutions except for the lower house of Parliament. Colonel Michael Randrianirina, who led a mutiny of an elite army unit over the weekend, said the military would run the country alongside a transitional government for up to two years while elections are arranged. President Andry Rajoelina’s whereabouts remain unclear; he is reportedly in hiding and may have left the country. He has refused to resign despite growing calls for his exit following weeks of protests, which began as a youth-led outcry over water and power utilities before evolving into a broader rejection of his leadership.

items.title: Military says it has seized power in Madagascar after president moves to 'safe place'
items.standfirst: The military promises elections within two years, but President Rajoelina insists he is still in charge.
items.content: The military promises elections within two years, but President Rajoelina insists he is still in charge.

items.title: Gen Z risks 'being marginalised' in Madagascar political overhaul as army takes power, expert says
items.standfirst: An elite Madagascar military unit said Tuesday it had taken power of the Indian Ocean nation after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina following weeks of anti-government protests led by young people. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Madagascar expert Dr Luke Freeman of University College London says that Gen Z protesters risk being left out of the overhaul of the political system.
items.content: An elite Madagascar military unit said Tuesday it had taken power of the Indian Ocean nation after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina following weeks of anti-government protests led by young people. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Madagascar expert Dr Luke Freeman of University College London says that Gen Z protesters risk being left out of the overhaul of the political system.

items.title: Military seizes power in Madagascar following anti-government protests
items.standfirst: The army in Madagascar seized power on Tuesday, days after the president went into hiding saying he feared for his life after several weeks of massive anti-government protests.
items.content: The army in Madagascar seized power on Tuesday, days after the president went into hiding saying he feared for his life after several weeks of massive anti-government protests. (Image credit: Brian Inganga)

items.title: Elite military unit says it has seized power in Madagascar
items.standfirst: Announcement comes after country’s parliament impeaches president after weeks of anti-government protestsAn elite military unit said it had taken power in Madagascar on Tuesday, after the country’s parliament impeached president Andry Rajoelina after weeks of anti-government protests.Rajoelina, who said on Monday in a Facebook Live video that he had gone into hiding after attempts to kill him, had refused demands to step down, but the demonstrators won the backing of the influential Capsat unit at the weekend. Continue reading...
items.content: Announcement comes after country’s parliament impeaches president after weeks of anti-government protestsAn elite military unit said it had taken power in Madagascar on Tuesday, after the country’s parliament impeached president Andry Rajoelina after weeks of anti-government protests.Rajoelina, who said on Monday in a Facebook Live video that he had gone into hiding after attempts to kill him, had refused demands to step down, but the demonstrators won the backing of the influential Capsat unit at the weekend. Continue reading...

items.title: Dramatic day sees army unit claim power in Madagascar
items.standfirst: The military in Madagascar is now in charge after the president fled and the parliament voted to impeach him.
items.content: The military in Madagascar is now in charge after the president fled and the parliament voted to impeach him.

items.title: Madagascar military announces it has taken power amid mass protests
items.standfirst: An elite Madagascar military unit said it has taken power in the country after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina on October 14, 2025. Earlier in the day, the president had announced the dissolution of the lower house in a failed attempt to block the vote.
items.content: An elite Madagascar military unit said it has taken power in the country after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina on October 14, 2025. Earlier in the day, the president had announced the dissolution of the lower house in a failed attempt to block the vote.

items.title: Fast-changing political situation in Madagascar as military says it has taken power
items.standfirst: Madagascar's military says it has taken power amidst mass protests and the President's flight. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle analyses the fast-changing situation.
items.content: Madagascar's military says it has taken power amidst mass protests and the President's flight. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle analyses the fast-changing situation.

items.title: Madagascar president says he fled country in fear for his life
items.standfirst: Andry Rajoelina does not announce resignation in speech broadcast on social media after military rebellionMadagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, said he had fled the country in fear for his life after a military rebellion but did not announce his resignation in a speech broadcast on social media late on Monday from an undisclosed location.The 51-year-old has faced weeks of gen Z-led anti-government protests, which reached a pivotal point on Saturday when an elite military unit joined the protests and called for the president and other ministers to step down. That prompted Rajoelina to say that an illegal attempt to seize power was under way in the Indian Ocean island and to leave the country. Continue reading...
items.content: Andry Rajoelina does not announce resignation in speech broadcast on social media after military rebellionMadagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, said he had fled the country in fear for his life after a military rebellion but did not announce his resignation in a speech broadcast on social media late on Monday from an undisclosed location.The 51-year-old has faced weeks of gen Z-led anti-government protests, which reached a pivotal point on Saturday when an elite military unit joined the protests and called for the president and other ministers to step down. That prompted Rajoelina to say that an illegal attempt to seize power was under way in the Indian Ocean island and to leave the country. Continue reading...

ai_summary: An elite army unit in Madagascar announced it had seized power.
The military dissolved most governing institutions, except the lower house.
The military plans to run the country with a transitional government.
Elections are promised within two years, according to the military.
President Rajoelina's whereabouts are currently unknown.

bullet_summary: Trump stated that the vessel was "affiliated with a Designated…

President Trump said the vessel belonged to "narcoterrorists" and that it was "trafficking narcotics
“The strike was conducted in International Waters, and six male narcoterrorists aboard the vessel were killed in the strike,” Trump said in a statement on his Truth Social social media platform

items.content: Tuesday's strike is the fifth known US attack on a vessel off the Venezuelan coast, bringing the total death toll to 27.

items.title: Trump says six were killed in US strike on another boat allegedly carrying drugs near Venezuela
items.standfirst: UN has condemned US strikes on small boats it believes to be trafficking drugs as extrajudicial executionsUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump announced on Tuesday that the United States has struck another small boat that he accuses of carrying drugs in waters off the coast of Venezuela, killing six people aboard.“The strike was conducted in International Waters, and six male narcoterrorists aboard the vessel were killed in the strike,” Trump said in a statement on his Truth Social social media platform. “No U.S. Forces were harmed.” Continue reading...
items.content: UN has condemned US strikes on small boats it believes to be trafficking drugs as extrajudicial executionsUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump announced on Tuesday that the United States has struck another small boat that he accuses of carrying drugs in waters off the coast of Venezuela, killing six people aboard.“The strike was conducted in International Waters, and six male narcoterrorists aboard the vessel were killed in the strike,” Trump said in a statement on his Truth Social social media platform. “No U.S. Forces were harmed.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says new strike kills six 'narcoterrorists' off Venezuela
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said Tuesday that a strike on a vessel allegedly smuggling drugs from Venezuela to the United States killed six “narcoterrorists”, bringing the total death toll in such operations to at least 27. Many experts question the legality of using lethal force in international waters against suspects who have not been charged.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said Tuesday that a strike on a vessel allegedly smuggling drugs from Venezuela to the United States killed six “narcoterrorists”, bringing the total death toll in such operations to at least 27. Many experts question the legality of using lethal force in international waters against suspects who have not been charged.

ai_summary: The US struck another boat off the coast of Venezuela.
President Trump announced the strike, which killed six people.
The US claims the vessel was involved in drug trafficking.
This is the fifth known US attack on a vessel in the area.
The UN has condemned the US strikes as extrajudicial executions.

items.title: Trump posthumously awards Charlie Kirk the Presidential Medal of Freedom
items.standfirst: President presented award to Kirk’s widow, Erika, on what would have been the far-right commentator’s 32nd birthdayDonald Trump posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian award in the United States, to the assassinated far-right commentator Charlie Kirk at the White House on Tuesday.Kirk, who was shot at an event at Utah Valley University in September, was among the most significant rightwing activists in the modern political era, galvanizing a younger generation of conservatives to engage in politics and support Trump’s candidacy ahead of the 2024 election. Continue reading...
items.content: President presented award to Kirk’s widow, Erika, on what would have been the far-right commentator’s 32nd birthdayDonald Trump posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian award in the United States, to the assassinated far-right commentator Charlie Kirk at the White House on Tuesday.Kirk, who was shot at an event at Utah Valley University in September, was among the most significant rightwing activists in the modern political era, galvanizing a younger generation of conservatives to engage in politics and support Trump’s candidacy ahead of the 2024 election. Continue reading...

Its spokesperson said that China would “fight to the end” in trade talks. Continue reading...

Its spokesperson said that China would “fight to the end” in trade talks. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Trump posthumously awarded Charlie Kirk the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

Kirk was a far-right commentator and activist.
Kirk was a founder of Turning Point USA.
The event took place in the White House Rose Garden.

items.title: French PM Lecornu pledges to suspend 2023 pension reform
items.standfirst: In the face of an unprecedented political crisis, France's re-appointed prime minister Sébastien Lecornu proposed suspending President Emmanuel Macron's signature pension reform enacted in 2023. Speaking before parliament, Lecornu warned however of the estimated cost of such a move as he pressed lawmakers to agree on next year's budget. Also in the segment, the US and China have started collecting new tit-for-tat port fees imposed on each other's maritime transport and shipping industry.

Speaking before parliament, Lecornu warned however of the estimated cost of such a move as he pressed lawmakers to agree on next year's budget. Also in the segment, the US and China have started collecting new tit-for-tat port fees imposed on each other's maritime transport and shipping industry.

items.title: Second time a charm? French PM Lecornu offers concessions to hostile parliament
items.standfirst: Was it enough for France’s minority government to pass the first hurdle of a trigger-happy hostile parliament that can pass a vote of no-confidence at any time? Reappointed prime minister Sébastien Lecornu offering a suspension of Emmanuel Macron's flagship reform, the raising of the retirement age. We'll review the general policy speech of a Lecornu who this time at least made it to the National Assembly. Last week, his initial coalition government imploded spectacularly after a mere 14 hours.

bullet_summary: Reported by BBC World, Al Jazeera, Politico

items.title: Man who set fire to Pennsylvania governor’s mansion jailed
items.standfirst: Cody Balmer pleaded guilty to arson and attempted murder for starting the fire in April while Shapiro and his family were inside. They escaped safely.
items.content: Cody Balmer pleaded guilty to arson and attempted murder for starting the fire in April while Shapiro and his family were inside. They escaped safely.

items.title: Suspect in US arson attack at Pennsylvania governor’s mansion pleads guilty
items.standfirst: Cody Balmer told police he had planned to attack Democratic Governor Josh Shapiro with a sledgehammer at his home.
items.content: Cody Balmer told police he had planned to attack Democratic Governor Josh Shapiro with a sledgehammer at his home.

items.title: Pennsylvania man pleads guilty in arson attack at governor’s mansion while Shapiro’s family slept
items.standfirst: Under a plea deal, Cody Balmer was sentenced to 25 to 50 years in prison.
items.content: A man who scaled an iron security fence in the middle of the night, eluded police and used beer bottles filled with gasoline to ignite the occupied Pennsylvania governor’s mansion pleaded guilty Tuesday to attempted murder and other charges. Cody Balmer, 38, also entered pleas to terrorism, 22 counts of arson, aggravated arson, burglary, aggravated assault of Gov. Josh Shapiro, 21 counts of reckless endangerment and loitering in the April 13 attack that did millions of dollars in damage to the state-owned brick building. Under a plea deal, Balmer was sentenced to 25 to 50 years in prison. Shapiro and members of his family had to be awakened and evacuated, but no one was injured. The multiple endangerment charges reflected the number of people in the residence at the time, including the governor’s family, guests and state troopers. The fire was set hours after they celebrated the Jewish holiday of Passover with a Seder in the residence. Prosecutors played video clips that showed Molotov cocktails going off and a figure inside and outside the residence. Judge Deborah Curcillo called the video “horrific” and “very frightening.” Balmer told police he planned to beat Shapiro with a small sledgehammer if he had encountered him after breaking into the building, according to court documents. Balmer turned himself in the next afternoon to face charges of attempted homicide, terrorism, aggravated arson and aggravated assault. Police say Balmer broke in through the southern wing of the residence, into a room often used to entertain crowds and display art. Investigators recovered two broken glass beer bottles containing gasoline. The fire charred walls, tables, buffet serving dishes, plates and a piano. Window panes and brick around doors and windows were also damaged. Shapiro's Jewish faith and the attack during the Passover weekend raised questions about Balmer's motivation, but Balmer told The Associated Press in a May letter from jail that had not been a factor in his decision. “He can be Jewish, Muslim, or a purple people eater for all I care and as long as he leaves me and mine alone,” Balmer wrote. He said in a brief June 9 video interview from Camp Hill State Prison that he did think beforehand about whether children might be injured. “Does anyone ever consider children?” Balmer said in June. “It doesn't seem that way. I sure as hell did. I'm glad no one got hurt.” Asked why he felt Shapiro had somehow done him wrong, Balmer replied: “I'm not going to answer that.” Balmer’s mother said days after his arrest that she had tried to get him assistance for mental health issues, but “nobody would help.” Court proceedings had been delayed while he received mental health treatment, his lawyer has said. At a court hearing a few days after the fire, Balmer told a judge he was an unemployed welder with no income or savings and “a lot of children.” The residence, built in 1968, did not have sprinklers. Work to fix the damage and to bolster its security features continues.

ai_summary: Cody Balmer pleaded guilty to arson and attempted murder.
Balmer set fire to the Pennsylvania governor's mansion.
Governor Shapiro and his family were inside at the time.
Balmer planned to attack Governor Shapiro with a sledgehammer.
Balmer was sentenced to 25 to 50 years in prison.

clusters.title: A New Attack Lets Hackers Steal 2-Factor Authentication Codes From Android Phones
clusters.neutral_headline: New Attack Allows Hackers to Steal 2FA Codes on Android
bullet_summary: Reported by Wired, Ars Technica News

items.title: A New Attack Lets Hackers Steal 2-Factor Authentication Codes From Android Phones
items.standfirst: The malicious app required to make a “Pixnapping” attack work requires no permissions.
items.content: The malicious app required to make a “Pixnapping” attack work requires no permissions.

items.title: Hackers can steal 2FA codes and private messages from Android phones
items.standfirst: Malicious app required to make "Pixnapping" attack work requires no permissions.
items.content: Android devices are vulnerable to a new attack that can covertly steal two-factor authentication codes, location timelines, and other private data in less than 30 seconds. The new attack, named Pixnapping by the team of academic researchers who devised it, requires a victim to first install a malicious app on an Android phone or tablet. The app, which requires no system permissions, can then effectively read data that any other installed app displays on the screen. Pixnapping has been demonstrated on Google Pixel phones and the Samsung Galaxy S25 phone and likely could be modified to work on other models with additional work. Google released mitigations last month, but the researchers said a modified version of the attack works even when the update is installed. Like taking a screenshot Pixnapping attacks begin with the malicious app invoking Android programming interfaces that cause the authenticator or other targeted apps to send sensitive information to the device screen. The malicious app then runs graphical operations on individual pixels of interest to the attacker. Pixnapping then exploits a side channel that allows the malicious app to map the pixels at those coordinates to letters, numbers, or shapes.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: A new attack method allows hackers to steal two-factor authentication codes.
The attack targets Android phones.
The attack is called "Pixnapping".
The malicious app required for the attack needs no permissions.
Hackers can also steal private messages using this method.

items.content: The families of 24 dead hostages are still waiting to have their bodies returned from Gaza.

The deceased hostages were returned by Hamas.
The identified hostages are Guy Illouz, Bipin Joshi, Yossi Sharabi, and Daniel Peretz.
Families of twenty-four other dead hostages await body returns.
Finding the remaining hostages presents a massive challenge.

clusters.title: DNA test confirmed alleged stalker was not Madeleine McCann, court hears
clusters.neutral_headline: DNA Test Confirms Woman Was Not Missing Madeleine McCann
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, BBC Top Stories

items.title: DNA test confirmed alleged stalker was not Madeleine McCann, court hears
items.standfirst: Investigating officer says he went against procedure to test Julia Wandelt, accused of campaign of harassment against McCann familyAn alleged stalker’s claim to be Madeleine McCann was ruled out after a DNA test proved conclusively she was not the missing girl, police have revealed in court.Julia Wandelt, 24, is accused of a campaign of harassment against the family of Madeleine, who went missing from Praia da Luz in Portugal in 2007 at the age of three. Continue reading...
items.content: Investigating officer says he went against procedure to test Julia Wandelt, accused of campaign of harassment against McCann familyAn alleged stalker’s claim to be Madeleine McCann was ruled out after a DNA test proved conclusively she was not the missing girl, police have revealed in court.Julia Wandelt, 24, is accused of a campaign of harassment against the family of Madeleine, who went missing from Praia da Luz in Portugal in 2007 at the age of three. Continue reading...

items.title: DNA test proved woman accused of stalking McCanns was not missing Madeleine, court hears
items.standfirst: Julia Wandelt and Karen Spragg deny stalking Kate and Gerry McCann over several years.
items.content: Julia Wandelt and Karen Spragg deny stalking Kate and Gerry McCann over several years.

ai_summary: A DNA test proved a woman was not Madeleine McCann.
The woman was accused of stalking the McCann family.
Julia Wandelt claimed to be Madeleine McCann.
The court heard details of the investigation.
Karen Spragg also denies stalking the McCanns.

clusters.title: Three police officers killed in Italy after explosion at house during eviction
clusters.neutral_headline: Police Officers Killed in Explosion During Eviction in Italy
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, Sky News World

items.title: Three police officers killed in Italy after explosion at house during eviction
items.standfirst: Two men and one woman arrested after explosion in Castel d’Azzano, which police believe to have been intentionalAn explosion at a farmhouse near Verona killed three police officers and injured at least 13 others, officials said on Tuesday.Police were attempting to conduct an eviction when the house blew up overnight in Castel d’Azzano, in northern Italy, in what is suspected to be an intentional act of violence. Continue reading...
items.content: Two men and one woman arrested after explosion in Castel d’Azzano, which police believe to have been intentionalAn explosion at a farmhouse near Verona killed three police officers and injured at least 13 others, officials said on Tuesday.Police were attempting to conduct an eviction when the house blew up overnight in Castel d’Azzano, in northern Italy, in what is suspected to be an intentional act of violence. Continue reading...

items.title: Police officers sent to evict three siblings killed in gas explosion in Italy
items.standfirst: Three police officers have been killed after they opened a door to a rural Italian farmhouse that had been intentionally filled with gas, igniting a massive explosion.
items.content: Three police officers have been killed after they opened a door to a rural Italian farmhouse that had been intentionally filled with gas, igniting a massive explosion.

ai_summary: Three police officers died in an explosion near Verona, Italy.
The explosion occurred during an eviction attempt.
The explosion happened at a farmhouse in Castel d'Azzano.
Police suspect the explosion was an intentional act.
Two men and one woman were arrested in connection.
